author: Jeremy Armstrong
title: Mum-of-two deported to Singapore 'for spending time with sick parents' despite being married to Brit for 27 years
text:
The 52-year-old said she was unable to contact her lawyer (Photo: gofundme) Share Get daily   
A loving gran has been forcibly removed from the UK with just the clothes on her back and £12 in her pocket - despite being married to a Brit for the past 27 years. 
Distraught Irene Clennell was deported to Singapore where she has no home, no money and no belongings. 
The mum-of-two was taken from a Glasgow detention centre without the chance to say good bye to her loved ones. 
Heartbroken husband John has written to Theresa May to protest. 
A campaign in his wife’s name, ‘Bring Irene Home’, has raised £30,000 towards a legal fight to bring her back. 
Supporters warn the move has echoes of Donald Trump ’s ‘inhumane and intolerant’ attitude towards immigration in the US. 
Irene, 53, who is main carer for her seriously ill husband, was put aboard a flight from Edinburgh to Singapore at 3.30pm on Sunday. Clennell with her husband John who she has been married to for 27 years (Photo: (c) North News & Pictures ltd) 
Waiting for take-off, she told how she had no time to say good bye to her loved ones, including her two children. 
She told Buzzfeed : “They came to get me this morning and said they have already given me a chance. 
“Now I am on the plane. Four people are taking me to Singapore. I don’t know what I will do when I land. 
“I called my sister in Singapore and she said she cannot put me up, so I just don’t know. 
“How can I stay anywhere? I don’t have a wallet with me, I’ve got about £12 in my pocket. 
“I don’t even have my clothes, they are at home. I just have what they took from the detention centre.” 
Former gas fitter John, 50, who relied on his wife for full-time care, told how she had ‘nowhere to go’. Read More Gran being deported to Singapore despite being married to Brit for 27 years admits she's "frightened" at prospect 
He added: “We went up to see her on Friday at the detention centre and she was in good spirits. 
“We have been fighting all along to get bail for her so that she could come home while it was sorted out. 
“To us it seemed like red tape that just needed to be cut through, we thought she’d be coming home and so did Irene. 
“The idea that they would actually go through with his and send her to Singapore just seemed so ridiculous that it couldn’t happen. The mum-of-two was held at Dungavel Detention Centre in South Lanarkshire (Photo: Daily Record) 
“But suddenly it has. Who is this helping? There are so many people coming into this country illegally so why deport someone with roots and a loving family, in the place she has lived for so many years? 
“I just don’t understand it and I think we’ve been terribly let down by the Government.” 
His sister Angela Clennell, 51, added: “They just came and removed her without prior warning. 
“It’s unbelievable.” 
Irene married John in 1990 and was given indefinite leave to remain. 
But she fell foul of foreign office red tape when she returned to Singapore to care for her sick parents in the late 90s. 
They have since died. 
She fought to regain indefinite leave to remain here, and was granted it by the Home Office in October 2008. 
Throughout all this time the couple, who met in a London pub in 1988, have had a home in the UK, and were living in Ouston, Co Durham. Their son John is 26 and has a year old daughter, Alana. Their younger son Sonny is 24. 
Irene was sent to Dungavel House Removal Centre in Lanarkshire after a routine appointment with the immigration service in Middlebrough six weeks ago. 
A Home Office spokesman said: “All applications for leave to remain in the UK are considered on their individual merits and in line with the immigration rules. 
“We expect those with no legal right to remain in the country to leave.” 
Lib Dem Shadow Home Secretary Brian Paddick warned the case highlighted the ‘irrationality and inhumanity of our immigration system’. 
He added: “When the rules are this arbitrary and rigid, anyone can find themselves on the wrong side of them. 
“This Conservative government’s lack of empathy is destroying Britain’s reputation as an open and tolerant country. 
“The Home Secretary must intervene immediately to bring Mrs Clennell home, give her the opportunity to appeal and prevent any further distress being caused to her and her family." Like us on Facebook
